sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving aqueous solutions
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) in aqueous solution at 298 K, given that the concentrations of both solutions are 1 mol/L and the reaction produces sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O)?
message_2:
The reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is a neutralization reaction, which can be represented by the following balanced chemical equation:

HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) â†’ NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)

The standard enthalpy change for this reaction, also known as the enthalpy of neutralization, is the heat released when one mole of an acid reacts with one mole of a base to form one mole of water. For strong acids and strong bases, like HCl and NaOH, the enthalpy of neutralization is relatively constant and can be approximated as -55.9 kJ/mol.

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between HCl and NaOH at 298 K is approximately -55.9 kJ/mol.
